Jean-Noël Rivasseau wrote:
>
> Hi and thanks for the reply. Just for clarification, when you mean
> make an index, you are suggesting to make a manual index (like in a
> DB)? Something like the list of URLs, and the offset into the arc
> file?
>






Yes. You could start with that (Thats the default output when you run 
./bin/arcreader IIRC).  You can sort and binary search or get all 
fancy-pants -- or lazy -- and populate a bdb or lucene, etc., and ask it 
questions  Or just give your ARCs to wayback and ask it 
(http://archive-access.sourceforge.net/projects/wayback/).

St.Ack


>
> Jean-Noel
>
> On Wed, Jul 30, 2008 at 6:35 PM, stack <stack@... 
> <mailto:stack%40duboce.net>> wrote:
> > Make an index and search that. Make the index concurrent to the writing
> > of ARC itself -- you'd need to subclass the ARC Writer to accomplish
> > this probably -- or make the index post-crawl. If you run
> > ./bin/arcreader, it dumps out a line per record. You could start with
> > this. Later you could sort them, etc. Or, just use an instance of
> > wayback and ask it which ARC the URL resides in.
> > St.Ack
> >
> > Jean-Noël Rivasseau wrote:
> >>
> >> Hello,
> >>
> >> My task is the following one: I need to search for a specific URL in
> >> the ARC file. From reading the Javadocs it seems there is no facility
> >> for doing this, other than iterating through ALL records and manually
> >> checking the URL all the time. Obviously this is not very nice from a
> >> performance point of view.
> >>
> >> Is there any alternative way of doing this? Does someone know of
> >> reasonably modern and maintained tool to do this, or am I just on my
> >> own? If I am, I would appreciate help/hints for implementing this.
> >>
> >> Jean-Noel
> >>
> >>
> >
> >
>
>
